detaileddescription.para: The function runloop_post() adds callbacks to a Runloop. The following typedef gives the signature of the kind of functions that can be posted as callbacks to a runloop.

detaileddescription.para: A Runloop instance can be create in new dynamic memory with runloop_new(), or in already allocated memory with runloop_init().
In the case of runloop_init() it is the callers responsibility to ensure the memory pointed to by athis is large enough. That greater than sizeof(Runloop).
The following is the recommended way to use runloop_init(): Runloopmyrunloop; runloop_init(&myrunloop);
The function runloop_free() should only be called on a runloop instance created with runloop_new().
A Runloop holds pointers to other dynamic objects and is responsible for the lifetime of some of those objects. Thus to avoid memory leaks a Runloop must be de-initialized correctly.
The function runloop_deinit() will correctly free all the objects pointed at by a runloop instance but will not free the memory directly occupied by the runloop object.
runloop_free() will call runloop_deinit() and also free the memory occupied by the Runloop instance.
Start a Runloop. A Runloop is always doing one of the following things:

listitem.para: is inside a call to epoll_wait() waiting for events to fire
processing the file descriptors and events returned by epoll_wait()
running down its list of waiting callback functions and calling them one at a time.

detaileddescription.para: The function runloop_run() only returns when there are no file descriptors to epoll_wait() on and no callbacks waiting to be called.

Hence before calling runloop_run() you must have some file descriptors being waited on for events and/or some callbacks that have been added to the Runloop to be called. Otherwise the runloop_run() call will return immediately.

parameterdescription.para: time_t a timeout interval the runloop will terminate when this timeout expires if -1 the runloop will run forever. In this project values other than -1 are only used in testing

detaileddescription.para:
Adds a function to a Runloop callback list.
runloop
A RunloopRef
callback_function
A pointer to the callback function
context_arg
This is a pointer used by the callback to gain access to its context. it can be a pointer to anything. It not used by the Runloop.

memberdef.argsstring: (RunloopRef athis, int fd, uint32_t interest, RunloopWatcherRef wref)
memberdef.name: runloop_register

memberdef.argsstring: (RunloopRef athis, int fd, uint32_t interest, RunloopWatcherRef wref)
memberdef.name: runloop_reregister

detaileddescription.para: A RunloopTimer is a spcial type of RunloopWatcher that make it easy to use a Runloop to implement single shot and repeating timers.

memberdef.argsstring: (RunloopTimerRef athis, PostableFunction cb, void *ctx, uint64_t interval_ms, bool repeating)
memberdef.name: runloop_timer_register

memberdef.argsstring: (RunloopTimerRef athis, PostableFunction cb, void *ctx, uint64_t interval_ms, bool repeating)
memberdef.name: runloop_timer_rearm_old

memberdef.argsstring: (RunloopRef rl, PostableFunction cb, void *ctx, uint64_t interval_ms, bool repeating)
memberdef.name: runloop_timer_set

detaileddescription.para: Convenience intrface for timers
After the call to runloop_timer_clear the timerref is invalid and muts not be ised
RunloopListener is a special kind of RunloopWatcher that is intended spcifically for situations where code is a server of sometype waiting for a listen() call to return signalling a new connection.

RunloopStreamRef is a special type of watcher designed to watch stream style file descriptors (such a sockets and pipes) to detect when such an fd is ready to perform a read operation or ready to perform a write operation without BLOCKING. This type of watcher is intended for situations where a single thread may be performing both read and write operations on the same fd and on multiple file descriptors.

memberdef.argsstring: (RunloopStreamRef athis, PostableFunction read_postable_cb, void *read_arg, PostableFunction write_postable_cb, void *write_arg)
memberdef.name: runloop_stream_arm_both

detaileddescription.para: Async io is a more convenient interface for reading and writing data to fd's like sockets.
It is a proactor interface rather than the reactor provided by the runloop_stream interface above

memberdef.argsstring: (AsioStreamRef stream_ref, void *buffer, long max_length, AsioReadcallback cb, void *arg)
memberdef.name: asio_stream_read

memberdef.argsstring: (AsioStreamRef stream_ref, void *buffer, long length, AsioWritecallback cb, void *arg)
memberdef.name: asio_stream_write

detaileddescription.para: epoll provides a facility to create a file descriptor that is not attached to any file/pipe/device and to "fire" events on that file descriptor that can be waited for using the epoll call. This facility provides a mechanism to create and wait on arbitary event sources.

memberdef.argsstring: (RunloopEventfdRef athis, PostableFunction postable, void *arg, uint64_t watch_what)
memberdef.name: runloop_eventfd_change_watch

detaileddescription.para: An eventfd_queue is a queue intended between threads where the act of adding an element triggers an epoll eventfd to the receiving thread.
The queue is protected by a condition variable and mutex
A runloop_queue_watcher is the mechanism a thread uses to recieve an event whenever a new entry is added to the queue by the same or a different thread.

memberdef.argsstring: (RunloopQueueWatcherRef athis, PostableFunction postable_cb, void *arg, uint64_t watch_what)
memberdef.name: runloop_queue_watcher_change_watch

detaileddescription.para: A RunloopInterthreadQueue is a second implementation of an EventfdQueue with added functionality (as you can see from the fact that there are more functions). It is specialized to be part of a Runloop so that other threads can submit work to a Runloop. An instance of a RunloopInterthreadQueue is used to implement the function
runloop_interthread_post()
